52EE54CE691B4C368131E229B6436289.description:
When inv estigating or describing a
sy stem, the boundaries and initial
conditions of the sy stem need to be
defined and their inputs and outputs
analy zed and described using models.

6D4B763284A84753913CC1346791C689.description:
The functions and properties of natural
and designed objects and systems can be
inferred from their overall structure, the
way their components are shaped and
used, and the molecular substructures of
its various materials.

813DE686679A449DAB278B91D24DEF45.description:
Feedback (negative or positive) can
stabilize or destabilize a system.

7AF0DBB78E774CD591B5D369883F88FF.description:
Change and rates of change can be
quantified and modeled over very short or
very long periods of time. Some system
changes are irreversible.

41F2797BE7654E8BBB61D7D9BCC355BF.description:
Much of science deals with constructing
explanations of how things change and
how they remain stable.

D1CC4EB007744EE0B340E1241C7F1A3E.description:
Much of science deals with constructing
explanations of how things change and
how they remain stable.

056156C4E45A4EA0BCB39B428340BB96.description:
A lgebraic thinking is used to examine
scientific data and predict the effect of a
change in one v ariable on another (e.g.,
linear growth v s. exponential growth).

D78ED8B026334C82B05B5F6D53B0124F.description:
The significance of a phenomenon is
dependent on the scale, proportion, and
quantity at which it occurs.

3B749A7BAF26445793CF3561ECD80A70.description:
Empirical ev idence is needed to identify
patterns

396F7E805A364E519F9BDCA27701CA72.description: Energy drives the cycling of matter within and between systems.

797CD90FA71B4D3A98DFAC25AED2C35F.description:
The total amount of energy and matter in
closed systems is conserved.

DB8386E727AA4DE8B15EA184E4FAA2CC.description:
In nuclear processes, atoms are not
conserv ed, but the total number of
protons plus neutrons is conserv ed

B726EF7BC06E429E9ABADE48C37A659F.description:
Energy cannot be created or destroy ed–
only mov ed between one place and
another place, between objects and/or
fields, or between sy stems

92AB334A74CE4674852F26A4E184FED4.description:
Empirical evidence is required to
differentiate between cause and
correlation and make claims about specific
causes and effects.

D4C6B445683843BB8CF0ECEE9DEA2B56.description:
A toms of each element emit and absorb characteristic
frequencies of light. These characteristics allow
identification of the presence of an element, ev en in
microscopic quantities.

02D68DA5BBE641CD8932678DC7759C66.description:
Geologists use seismic waves and their reflection at interfaces
between layers to probe structures deep in the planet

2CEA1A36FACF4BE6B64065718FAC3666.description:
Nuclear Fusion processes in the center of the sun release
the energy that ultimately reaches Earth as radiation.

0BB3E946A89843C781E13DF7E5CCEBEA.description: Energy in Chemical Processes and Everyday Life

8A3F15F38CE44681818B875EEDCE0DEA.description:
Spontaneous radioactiv e decay s follow a characteristic
exponential decay law. Nuclear lifetimes allow radiometric
dating to be used to determine the ages of rocks and
other materials.

406C1E93CFC84C448EB38D35B1A192DA.description:
Through computer simulations and other studies, important
discov eries are still being made about how the ocean, the
atmosphere, and the biosphere interact and are modified in
response to human activ ities.

C4E4AE2807A84F52921D1CAB17298262.description:
Though the magnitudes of human impacts are greater than
they hav e ev er been, so too are human abilities to model,
predict, and manage current and future impacts.

F3D19E4D6F774E858104F4307ED49543.description:
Scientists and engineers can make major contributions by
dev eloping technologies that produce less pollution and
waste and that preclude ecosy stem degradation.

161710A1A9CE4AB980912C5CB636E396.description:
The sustainability of human societies and the biodiv ersity that
supports them requires responsible management of natural
resources.

3431EBA4F2BF474AAA2BE29B2003D3E4.description:
Natural hazards and other geologic ev ents hav e shaped the
course of human history ; [they ] hav e significantly altered the
sizes of human populations and hav e driv en human
migrations.

69F2E08398974A2EBA51ED1F49A520C9.description:
 A ll forms of energy production and other resource extraction
hav e associated economic, social, env ironmental, and
geopolitical costs and risks as well as benefits. New
technologies and social regulations can change the balance of
these factors

89A2EF0DBE97493191F8F2619B6E0753.description:
Resource av ailability has guided the dev elopment of human
society .

4E105AC6A57343FA850E4698F07C36EE.description:
The many dynamic and delicate feedbacks between the biosphere
and other Earth systems cause a continual co-evolution of Earth’s
surface and the life that exists on it.

C1135D0E4C964BD5A4B8B8388411B880.description:
C urrent models predict that, although future regional climate
changes will be complex and v aried, av erage global
temperatures will continue to rise. The outcomes predicted
by global climate models strongly depend on the amounts of
human-generated greenhouse gases added to the
atmosphere each y ear and by the way s in which these gases
are absorbed by the ocean and biosphere.

89F17558FB344997868D30383CB5D5C1.description:
Changes in the atmosphere due to human activity have increased
carbon dioxide concentrations and thus affect climate.

A0B9960CD4D746E8ABB38F2DA51134AF.description:
Gradual atmospheric changes were due to plants and other
organisms that captured carbon dioxide and released oxygen.

500B25F30234426CB221C3536052901C.description:
The foundation for Earth’s global climate systems is the
electromagnetic radiation from the sun, as well as its reflection,
absorption, storage, and redistribution among the atmosphere,
ocean, and land systems, and this energy’s re-radiation into
space.

60B90E2A2EF3422C870605260534686D.description:
The abundance of liquid water on Earth’s surface and its unique
combination of physical and chemical properties are central to the
planet’s dynamics. These properties include water’s exceptional
capacity to absorb, store, and release large amounts of energy,
transmit sunlight, expand upon freezing, dissolve and transport
materials, and lower the viscosities and melting points of rocks.

A42F72F265694F688E798F82A715914C.description: The Roles of Water in Earth's Surface Processes

CDAA6353F07D40899351FBEAC51E37E4.description:
Plate tectonics is the unifying theory that explains the past and
current movements of the rocks at Earth’s surface and provides a
framework for understanding its geologic history. Plate
movements are responsible for most continental and ocean-floor
features and for the distribution of most rocks and minerals within
Earth’s crust.

58A6D390B93946E999CDFE15585E5A15.description:
The radioactive decay of unstable isotopes continually generates
new energy within Earth’s crust and mantle, providing the primary
source of the heat that drives mantle convection. Plate tectonics
can be viewed as the surface expression of mantle convection.

1BB7123142B04EE298BD113D2AEFEE2D.description:
Plate tectonics is the unify ing theory that explains the
past and current mov ements of the rocks at Earth’s
surface and prov ides a framework for understanding its
geologic history .

DC7122DF560C46D49CE3B9CDE02A9F5C.description:
Plate Tectonics and Large-Scale System
Interactions

B8A4BF8615424749B3B74EC8414023DF.description:
 The geological record shows that changes to global and regional
climate can be caused by interactions among changes in the sun’s
energy output or Earth’s orbit, tectonic events, ocean circulation,
volcanic activity, glaciers, vegetation, and human activities. These
changes can occur on a variety of time scales from sudden (e.g.,
volcanic ash clouds) to intermediate (ice ages) to very long-term
tectonic cycles.

E1EADB052BD54EDFA257FF74919B170E.description:
Evidence from deep probes and seismic waves, reconstructions of
historical changes in Earth’s surface and its magnetic field, and an
understanding of physical and chemical processes lead to a model
of Earth with a hot but solid inner core, a liquid outer core, a solid
mantle and crust. Motions of the mantle and its plates occur
primarily through thermal convection, which involves the cycling
of matter due to the outward flow of energy from Earth’s interior
and gravitational movement of denser materials toward the
interior

E38FE3C940C04CEEBCF82586C2C0F107.description:
Earth’s systems, being dynamic and interacting, cause feedback
effects that can increase or decrease the original changes.

8CB423B719D042659790CC423863C1E4.description:
A lthough activ e geologic processes, such as plate
tectonics and erosion, hav e destroy ed or altered most of
the v ery early rock record on Earth, other objects in the
solar sy stem, such as lunar rocks, asteroids, and
meteorites, hav e changed little ov er billions of y ears.
Study ing these objects can prov ide information about
Earth’s formation and early history .

A9D24A1DF58E41E3B1474B70782E5BC4.description:
C ontinental rocks, which can be older than 4 billion
y ears, are generally much older than the rocks of the
ocean floor, which are less than 200 million y ears old.

52D99BB84BB64458BB5894B3F8D4E0BA.description:
Cyclical changes in the shape of Earth’s orbit around the sun,
together with changes in the tilt of the planet’s axis of rotation,
both occurring over hundreds of thousands of years, have altered
the intensity and distribution of sunlight falling on the earth.
These phenomena cause a cycle of ice ages and other gradual
climate changes

DAC2229215FA4E0FA8E2F1BA8169EAFD.description:
Kepler’s laws describe common features of the motions
of orbiting objects, including their elliptical paths around
the sun. O rbits may change due to the grav itational
effects from, or collisions with, other objects in the solar
sy stem.

A8808557D1D448019D0E78F5813D2760.description:
O ther than the hy drogen and helium formed at the time
of the Big Bang, nuclear fusion within stars produces all
atomic nuclei lighter than and including iron, and the
process releases electromagnetic energy . Heav ier
elements are produced when certain massiv e stars
achiev e a supernov a stage and explode.

7A2BB5E2F08C4531902580BFF8014AC0.description:
The Big Bang theory is supported by observations of
distant galaxies receding from our own, of the measured
composition of stars and non-stellar gases, and of the
maps of spectra of the primordial radiation (cosmic
microwave background) that still fills the universe.

8318689B0CB64AB69FB223023B19C764.description:
The study of stars’ light spectra and brightness is used to
identify compositional elements of stars, their
movements, and their distances from Earth.

0B7DB0019B59430FB16B9C17D671E083.description:
The star called the sun is changing and will burn out ov er
a lifespan of approximately 10 billion y ears.

A972F85B7F88495A8432BB1F401BA40C.description: ESS1.A : The Universe and Its Stars

38E0B2B447994017833D8B2423D6FE69.description:
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those
relationships are being modified due to human activity.

95374F837D534DB888FDD412FD38632F.description:
Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the
current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth systems.

EBBF3D3AE0A543119AFBAE5C88143A8D.description: Evaluate or refine a technological solution that reduces impacts of human activities on natural systems.

0A172E07D10D42D390B90EF449BD8A67.description:
Create a computational simulation to illustrate the relationships among management of natural resources, the
sustainability of human populations, and biodiversity.

E4B342D22CF24F10919CFF1D6D9E43CB.description:
Evaluate competing design solutions for developing, managing, and utilizing energy and mineral resources
based on cost-benefit ratios.

ECCE33507F2B4064A38310D98268D583.description:
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the availability of natural resources, occurrence of natural
hazards, and changes in climate have influenced human activity.

65C10CFCF9FB424080CD70DBB1C19D2C.description:
Construct an argument based on evidence about the simultaneous coevolution of Earth’s systems and life on
Earth.

3ACCADC923A24A509DCC6624B29464FF.description:
Develop a quantitative model to describe the cycling of carbon among the hydrosphere, atmosphere,
geosphere, and biosphere.

41FEC217D73842439031AC9EC7863099.description:
Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface
processes.

B2891860F1164315A5EA6F9956D0659B.description:
Use a model to describe how variations in the flow of energy into and out of Earth’s systems result in changes
in climate. [

18C983974BDF43A1A67BF223A7582BB5.description: Develop a model based on evidence of Earth’s interior to describe the cycling of matter by thermal convection.

6157A0BF3ACF4561B64540513BA71D65.description:
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth’s surface can create feedbacks that
cause changes to other Earth systems.

CC081B660B8E478CBD512560A89F4CEF.description:
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and
temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features. [

7C0A186DD7E74A6D9D457106F534FEDB.description:
Apply scientific reasoning and evidence from ancient Earth materials, meteorites, and other planetary
surfaces to construct an account of Earth’s formation and early history.

4E4FBC42B6214E83A0D39C1D6CC75E8D.description:
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate
tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.

73D2DB7F9376409CA668AD93786C61BD.description:
Use mathematical or computational representations to predict the motion of orbiting objects in the solar
system.

EEA83F3893AE41928A048F726A8D0612.description: Communicate scientific ideas about the way stars, over their life cycle, produce elements

EE38AF5F88E740CD9DDB84C2565A94A9.description:
Construct an explanation of the Big Bang theory based on astronomical evidence of light spectra, motion of
distant galaxies, and composition of matter in the universe.

99CE536F6939436085D2A53423384D9E.description:
Develop a model based on evidence to illustrate the life span of the sun and the role of nuclear fusion in the
sun’s core to release energy that eventually reaches Earth in the form of radiation.
